reviewText:
Synchrom is a unique, relaxing, hard, beautiful and polished game.

You probably saw the video and wondered what the gameplay was about. We've all been there.

I think we can say the game is a boss-fight-shoot-them-up/rythm-game that can be played with only the mouse.

Sound simple? It is! But you will need to be extremely focused and reactive to beat advanced levels or make the highest scores.
Also, each level has its own music, rythm and patterns, renewing the gameplay and changing your approach of the boss.

If I had to find a negative point, I would say I was not really interested by the story behind the game, but that's a very minor drawback.

Definitely an original game that you should try, it's the kind of title you probably never played before.

reviewText: Great game! It get really hard, really fast but that's what makes it so rewarding. You don't need to be a hardcore gamer to enjoy it, though : earlier levels  are a decent challenge but really nothing insurmountable and you can very much progress at your own pace with the difficulty options.

reviewText:
That game just took 3hours of my time without me noticing.
Space musical shooter. Light, colored light everywhere! Damn pretty!
I like the atmosphere of this game, the light, the color, the soundtrack. On a gameplay level, the game is faster than your brain, really smooth (can't blame it when I loose...). I'd like to see it running on a touch device.
On the other side, I found it quite difficult! (Or it's my brain that can't process all the information).
There's a lot of things on screen (light beam, shields, power ups, rockets...) and it can be a bit hard to find where to shoot without dying.
Ok, so time to get back saving the universe!! (By the way, don't try the hard mode, you'll get hurt).
voteText: 9 of 9 people (100%) found this review helpful 1 person found this review funny

reviewText:
Synchrom is a game on its own.
Its uniqueness lies in the details, the first glimpse suggest basic elements, simple match-n-win concepts, but as soon as you get past the tutorial, you get surprised by how twisted, hard and punitive it can get.

Don't rely on the screenshots or videos, it needs to be experienced in order to understand how the very basics of this game can manipulate your mind.
When you think you get the grasp on it, you loose it right away. It excels at pushing you out of your comfort zone, throwing shapes and rhythms in your face, increasingly challenging your brain at every moment.

An unlock-as-you-score modifier system allows for high replayability, and it gets quickly additcive.
While the art could benefit some polish, the gameplay puts genuinely original ideas on the table, and it's something great nowadays !

This game sits close to Race The Sun, where playing require no effort, and where practise is its own reward.

reviewText:
Easy to play, hard to master!

Shoot in rythm with the right color to defeat bosses. The tutorial take 2 minutes. After that you have to fight bosses increasingly complex and aggressive.

This game need skills for hard levels but it's highly addictive

reviewText:
tl:dr version: download this game. You will feel good after playing it. I'm not even kidding.

Somewhat longer version:

Simply said, this game is smart. Entertaining and smart. It's a game that, for once, you can't just go about dumbly mashing buttons and fragging mobs. You'll have a tiny smidgin of thinking to do every nanosecond, which - and you'll experiment this for yourself - will actually make you feel like it improves your brain.

Synchrom could be a training program to help you play other games better. And it could be just that. But better yet, it has a theme. It has bosses. It has unlocks.

And it makes every beat of music a pulsing weapon that just feels good when you're synced and unlocking upgrades.

I don't regret downloading this, like I regret downloading 10 Gigs of DayZ.

- Game was fun
- Brain felt good
- Beats were awesome
- Shooting in sync to the beat felt great inside

1010 would feel great inside again.

reviewText: I've not played it a lot but I can feel this is the type of game you'll never want to stop play until you defeated the big f****g light bulb that doesn't want to let you win. The music is pretty neat ant the design makes you brain melt with all this colorful colorfullness. Great mix of rythm game and shmup.

reviewText:
This is a unique title, that is at the same time difficult, yet relaxing. A game that is easy to lose yourself into and before you know it it’s been 4 hours. (offline playtime for the win)

It’s gameplay is simple enough, take your mouse and rotate around a cube, match colors and break the cube away. The art is simple, and gorgeous with flashing lights and a color palette that doesn’t overwhelm. Everything else does though. ALL THE LASERS

There is a story here, but I can’t begin to tell you what it might really be about. That sounds bad, and on one hand it is. On the other though the gameplay itself kept me going. The game is punishing and difficult, and as you proceed with a higher score (maybe) you unlock additional stuff. YAY, we all like stuff.

Some issues I had, aside from the extreme difficulty spike (to be fair, I was warned it was hard.) Were that occasionally my mouse cursor (or Synchrom) would get stuck just for a moment at some point on the screen, as if my mouse was not responding. Then it would work, and I would die. I looked over other reviews to see if anyone else has had this issue, and I didn’t see any other reports. This could be something locally with our machine here though.

I do agree with one other review that stated they would be interested to see the game with touch controls. I think that it would fit well with the game, and possibly even be better than a mouse for controls. If I had a choice though I would love to see a controller supported for this game on PC.

For the moment of truth! Do we recommend this game?

Yes, it’s addictive in the way that puzzle games tend to be with the “one more high score-itis” Is that a thing? It should be. On top of that the low price point of 9.99 makes this easy to pick up, and I’ve already spent as much time as a short triple A title with it. If you really hate yourself, or you think you’re the best thing since sliced cheese then you can up the difficulty and see how long you last before you break something, or your head explodes, so there’s lots of replayability. Unless your head explodes, then there’s probably not much.

www.8bitlanparty.com

reviewText: This game mixes sound and color and manages to be relaxing and tense at the same time. It will définitely make your neurons sweat but once you get the hang of it, it's really rewarding! There are also many game modes and stuff to unlock.\nReally great and innovative game!

reviewText:
Synchrom is a solid offering for players looking for challenge and increasing difficulty, and I'm sure some players will end up hooked on the thrill of the scoring.

It's the kind of game that requires all your attention; understanding the rythm and the patterns is the key of success.

And if you feel bored and think you already mastered the game, you can still increase the difficulty with advanced gameplay features.

reviewText:
Very nice and immersive game which reminds me Rez, but with more reflex / reaction / fast decision making.
Color-based puzzling is also included in each of your shots : You have to aim the boss entities which are the same color of your cursor. And the color of your cursor will change according to the beat of the music.
First you target protective blocks of the boss, and finally you'll target its core: Each stage is divided into several musical phases where the boss entity wakes up and evolves as millstones are met.
This game will make you retry a lot, and I can assure you the music is not repetitive, and that each time you'll progress little by little.
